STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
September 25, 2025
Jennifer Stevens
Samaritas - Bay
1024 Professional Dr.
Flint, MI, 48532-3635
Re: License #:
SI #: 2025SIC0000855
Dear Ms. Stevens:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action
plan must be completed and routed in CWLM. If you desire technical assistance in
addressing these issues, please feel free to contact me. Failure to submit an acceptable
corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the please contact the area manager, Jessica
VandenHeuvel, at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
Enclosure
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0000855
Special Investigation Intake Date: July 15, 2025
License #: CB250296641
Licensee Group Organization: Samaritas
Licensee Designee: Rachel Sykes
Chief Administrator: Jennifer Stevens
Agency Name: SAMARITAS - BAY
Agency Address: 1024 PROFESSIONAL DR
FLINT, MI 48532-3635
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 01/13/2026
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose
8/15/2025 1:05PM Phone Interview
8/13/2025 9:28 AM Phone Interview
8/11/2025 3:46 pm Phone Other
7/25/2025 1:13 PM Email Document received or sent
7/25/2025 12:57 PM Phone Interview
7/25/2025 7:44 AM Phone Interview
7/23/2025 1:06 PM Phone Other
7/23/2025 12:58 PM Phone Other
7/23/2025 12:52 PM Phone Other
7/23/2025 9:24 AM Email Document received or sent
7/23/2025 9:09 AM Phone Interview
7/23/2025 7:59 AM Phone Other
7/18/2024 3:48 PM Email Documentation received or sent
7/18/2025 11:31 AM Email Documentation received or sent
7/18/2025 10:39 AM Phone Interview
7/16/2025 3:31 PM Phone Special Investigation Initiation
III. INVESTIGATION
1

Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207 Staff responsibilities.
Section (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be directly
Description responsible for all the following activities:
(b) Facilitating services and parenting time for children for
purposes of reunification.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The child has been in care for three years, is 9 years old but
educationally is at a preschool level and no IEP was looked into
until the child was at their current home for seven months.
Additionally, the child was not receiving mental health treatment
for several years before entering their current placement.
Investigation Interviews:
On 7/18/2025 I spoke with Department of Child Welfare
Licensing Analyst (DCWLA) by telephone related to the
complaint. DCWLA reported during a home visit with Foster
Parent A, Foster Parent A reported concerns. Foster Parent A
reported Child B was placed in her home on 12/6/2024, but the
system shows the placement as 12/7/24. Foster Parent A
reported that Child B, who is age 9, and who functions at a
preschool age level had been in care for three years, and no IEP
was looked into until Child B was placed with her. Nor was Child B
receiving mental health services prior to placement with her.
On 7/23/2025, I spoke with Program Manager (PM) about the
complaint by telephone. PM reported he and another program
manager took over Child B’s and her siblings’ case supervision in
May of 2025, following Foster Care Supervisor’s (FCS) departure
from the agency; and Child B’s case transferring to Foster Care
Worker 2 (FCW 2). PM reported Foster Parent A had reached out
to him with concerns related to Foster Care Worker 1 (FCW 1)
and FCS related to them not communicating well and Foster
Parent A feeling FCW 1 and FCS were not addressing her
requests timely, such as school related concern. PM reported he
felted Foster Parent A concerns rose to the grievance level, so he
shared the concerns with Chief Administrator (CA). It was agreed
Child B’s case would be transferred to FCW 2 who resided in the
same city that Foster Parent A resides so that this worker could
better meet the foster parent and child’s needs.
In regards to an IEP for Child B, PM reported when Child B was in
Child B’s prior foster home an IEP was requested, but due to the
child not being in the foster home long enough for the whole
process to go though, the IEP did not occur. Then Child B was
2

placed with Foster Parent A and an IEP was requested and is in
place. PM reported as far as therapy, FCW 1 was working with
Genesee County Health System(GHS); and according to reports
by FCW 1 during the time she was trying to get services in place,
no therapists were available, and the child was on a wait list until a
therapist could be assigned. PM reported FCW 1 would have
more details about the mental health services issues and other
matters.
On 7/25/2025, I interviewed FCW 2 by telephone. FCW 2 reported
only being assigned to Child B’s case since 5/12/2025. She
affirmed PM’s reasoning of poor communication between Foster
Parent A and FCW 1 being the cause as to why the case was
transferred to her. She reported FCW 1 kept Child B’s siblings
cases. FCW 2 reported Child B had had an IEP just prior to her
being assigned the case, with the IEP process starting on
3/25/2025 and being completed on 4/17/2025. As to why it took
so long for the IEP to get put in place for Child B, FCW 2 said
Foster Parent A told her, Foster Parent A was requesting the
services, but FCW 1 was not getting things done. Foster Parent A
reported that FCW 1 was reporting she was working on things, but
nothing ever got done. Foster Parent A reported it was FCW 1’s
way of doing things or no way; and FCW 1 would not listen to her.
FCW 2 reported when she took over Child B’s case the mental
health services Child B was in need of was therapy, and the
therapy and tutoring started on 7/8/2025. Child B is receiving
services via GHS. She was receiving in-home therapy, support
services, community living support (like life/social skills), and
respite was added. Child B goes to Day Care after school, and
during the summer. FCW 2 reported Child B was not getting
these service prior. FCW 2 reported Foster Parent A reported,
FCW 1 told her Child B did not need the services. FCW 2
reported believing that FCW 1 had worked on getting the services,
but they had not occurred.
FCW 2 reported at the case transfer meeting with FCW 1 and
FCS, who is no longer with the agency, they went over the case;
but FCW 1 did not report why these service were not in place. Nor
whether there were barriers to getting these services. FCW 1 and
FSC only reported Child B was on the wait list for therapeutic
services. She did not report knowledge of any paper work with
Foster Parent A’s address being somehow diverted to Child B’s
birth parent.
3

On 7/25/2025 I interviewed FCW 1 by telephone about the
complaint. FCW 1 reported initially being assigned to Child B’s
case in February 2023. She affirmed Child B’s case reassignment
to FCW 2 in May 2025, while she kept Child B’s siblings’ case.
She reported the case transfer happened because Foster Parent
A thought she was not doing her job. Foster Parent A was not
happy with her, but Foster Parent A was not seeing what she was
doing behind the scenes to accomplish things. Foster Parent A
also did not like how parenting times were being set up, but FCW
1 did not expand further. She reported at the end of her
assignment, Foster Parent A was hostile to her by sending text
messages in all CAPs.
FCW 1 denied Child B was not receiving therapeutic services prior
to her placement with Foster Parent A. She reported Child B was
placed in a relative placement with Fictive-Kin C, when she was
first assigned the case and Child B was receiving therapy in
school. Additionally, after Child B was replaced from Fictive-Kin
C’s home for a couple of months; and prior to her returning to
Fictive-Kin C’s care Child B was in therapy through Community
Mental Health. FCW 1 did not report the name of the Community
Mental Health (CMH) provider. She reported when Child B
returned to Fictive-Kin C’s home, Child B continued in therapy via
school. FCW 1 did not report the name of the school and was not
sure if the information was indicated in service plans. She also
reported when Child B was replaced to Caregiver E’s home, Child
B received therapy via Washtenaw County Community Mental
Health, with Therapist 1. FCW 1 reported having only a few
emails from Therapist 1 because Child B was only with Caregiver
E for a short while.
FCW 1 reported when Child B was placed with Foster Parent A, in
December 2024 Foster Parent A completed a referral for mental
health services via GHS. Child B was on the wait list all the while
FCW 1 remained assigned to the case. FCW 1 said during that
time, she had phone contact with the CMH caseworker to see if
there was anything she could do to move the process along.
She said Foster Parent A never asked for her assistance in having
things move along faster. Foster Parent A was the one informing
her of what was happening, i.e. the wait list, and of Child B
needing therapy because of intensive behaviors. FCW1 reported
Child B completed a psychological evaluation following the CMH
intake and that was what prompted the request for intensive
mental health services by Foster Parent A. FCW 1 said she never
received any paper work on that.
4

FCW 1 admitted when she first was assigned to Child B’s case in
February 2023, Child B did not have an IEP. She said Foster
Parent A was aware Child B needed to have an IEP when Child B
was placed. She said Child B had undergone an evaluation for an
IEP at her last school; and that she provided that to School 2.
FCW 1 said School 2 provided Foster Parent A with information: a
copy of an IEP, which Foster Parent A sent to her which she said
was an incorrect document. She reported School 2 completed
Child B’s IEP on 3/25/2025; and Foster Parent A texted her on
4/17/2025 telling her of the later state date. FCW 1 received a
copy of the IEP report on 5/1/2025. FCW denied not working to
receive timely services for Child B. She said she was doing her
job the best that she could, that this was a rough case.
On 8/13/2025 I interviewed Foster Parent A by telephone about
the allegations. Foster Parent A reported Child B was not in
therapy when Child B was placed with her on 12/6/2024. Child B
had previously been getting services via New Oakland reportedly
for suicidal ideations. She said Child B has not had such behavior
again. She said she tried to get Child B services via GHS. She
reported someone at GHS told her Child B’s worker could get
Child B a “warm welcome” and get her placed on the wait list
faster, but FCW 1 never did that. She said it took until February
2025 to get Child B’s services; and FCW 1 did not help in any
way. Currently Child B is receiving services for Post Traumatic
Stress Disorder, which includes teaching and coping skills, and
tutoring. Child B is also on medication now.
Foster Parent A reported FCW 1 told her FCW 1 would help her
get an IEP for Child B, but FCW 1 did not. FCW 1 told her they
needed Child B’s parent’s permission to get the IEP. Foster
Parent A said, she did not think that was true, given she had not
needed it prior, but she listened to FCW 1. She said a month went
by and FCW 1 never provided her with a parental permission slip.
She said she went to Child B’s school, and the school told her a
parental permission slip was not necessary. She said, once FCW
2 was assigned the case, FCW 2 said she was unable to help her
because FCW 1 never provided her information. Foster Parent A
said she ended up getting the IEP on her own. Foster Parent A
reported that this was the first time she has had a worker not to
help. She said she even filed a grievance and tried to get
assistance from Program Manager and Chief Administrator who
basically said they understood; and changed her worker to FCW
2.
5

On 8/15/2025, during an interview with Foster Parent E related to
another matter, Foster Parent E reported she was Child B’s 5th
foster care placement. She fostered Child B for five month. She
reported Child B was in therapy through Washtenaw County CMH;
which she got Child B into.
Document Review:
Child B’s MISACWIS case record which showed:
• Child A was placed in Samaritas’ care on 2/23/2023.
• She is a temporary court ward.
• Updated service plans (USP) completed by FCW 1 from
4/29/2023 to 4/16/2025.
o A 12/23/23-4/29/2023, and 4/30/2023- 7/29/2023
USP showing case documentation that Child B was
receiving therapy via school.
o Various USP’s after 7/27/2023 indicating an intake
appointment was attended by FCW for therapy,
child was in therapy or was in need of therapy.
o No indication about therapy or a lack of process
about getting therapy for Child B in the 1/25/2024-
4/23/2024 USP
o A social work contact in the 4/24/2024-7/22/2024
USP treatment plan that indicated Child B was in
process to get a new therapist after her
replacement.
o A 7/23/2024-10/18/2024 USP that indicated Child B
is in therapy weekly and her behavior issues have
reduced in the last two weeks.
o No indication about an IEP being in place or needed
in the earlier USPs; and a social work contact in the
10/27/2023-1/24/2024 USP that indicated an IEP is
needed and will be completed.
o A social work contact in the 10/19/2024-1/16/2025
USP that indicated a court hearing notation that an
IEP was to be completed. Additionally, a social work
case contact of a foster home visit that indicated
Child B is in need of a therapy intake and that the
foster parent is to complete the intake at GHS.
Another section of this 10/19/2024-1/16/2025 USP
indicated Child B is now in therapy.
o A 1/17/2025- 4/16/2025 USP which contained a
2/10/2025 foster home social work contact that
indicated Child B had a therapy intake. No date was
listed for that intake. Additionally, Child B also had
an evaluation for an IEP. A 3/10/2025 social contact
indicated a foster home visit occurred noting Child B
6

was in the process of completing an IEP at school.
This 3/10/2025 contact did not mention an update
on therapy but indicated a concern with Child B
squeezing and killing the family’s bird.
• The only service listed in the MISACWIS case service
section of the record for Child B was an evaluation/paid
mental health service for a Trauma Assessment on
8/11/2022 with Dr S. This section noted the service was
expected to begin on 8/11/2022 and continue until
11/11/2022.
• No specific documentation as to what action FCW 1 was
conducting to achieve completion of the IEP.
• Child B’s placement with Foster Parent A on 12/7/2024 to
the present is her sixth placement: the others are as
follows:
• 2/23/2023-7/13/2023 with Fictive-Kin C.
• 7/13/2023-9/6/2023 with Foster Parent D.
• 9/6/2023-6/17/2024 with Fictive-Kin C.
• 6/17/2024-11/20/2024 with Foster Parent E.
• 11/20/2024-12/7/2025 Foster Parent F.
Documents received from FCW 1:
• Behavior Assessment dated 12/10/2024 showing overall
basic testing for Child B.
• A 10/16/2024 initial eligibility testing for special education
for Child B via School 1.
• A 11/11/2024 Agreement to Extend Evaluation Timeline- so
that more information can be collected to determine Child
B’s specific learning disability.
• Two sensory profiles and psychological information
completed in October 2024.
• Child B’s starts at School 1 on 10/7/2024, which is where
an evaluation for an IEP for Child B reportedly started.
• No documentation of another IEP.
Child B’s IEP dated 3/25/2025 which:
• Referenced the aforementioned documents forms from
FCW 1.
• Indicated Child B qualifies for special education services
under the category of Otherwise Health Impairment.
A 7/16/2025 letter from Genesee Health System to FCW 2:
• Advised the therapist that will be providing individual and
family therapy to Child B.
7

Analysis Based on interviews and documents reviewed the evidence
showed Child B was receiving therapy prior to her placement with
Foster Parent A.
Once Child B was replaced to another county a new intake was
required, and Child B was placed on a wait list until she was
assigned a therapist. The record, nor FCW 1 provided proof of
efforts FCW 1 made to assist the foster parent in securing the
therapy change/reinstatement in a new county.
Nor that FCW 1 sought to secure a timely IEP for Child B. Child
B’s case documented a need for an IEP at least as far back as
October 2023 and documentation and reporting showed one was
started later in 2024, but not secured until after Child B’s
replacement with Foster Parent A.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED.
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12409 Education.
Section (1) An agency must ensure that, within 5 school days of
Description placement, an agency shall provide for the enrollment of each
child of school age, as defined by state law, into a school
program.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation A child was in placement for 19 days before entering school. The
foster care worker was not assisting the foster parent with needed
documents to get the child enrolled.
Investigation Interviews:
On 7/18/2025 I spoke with Department of Child Welfare
Licensing Analyst (DCWLA) by telephone related to the
complaint. DCWLA reported during a home visit with Foster
Parent A, Foster Parent A reported Child B was placed in her
home on 12/6/2024 but Child B did not get enrolled in school until
19 day later. Foster Parent A reported she was in need of Child
B’s birth certificate to get Child B in enrolled in school, as the
school had asked for that, but Foster Parent A reported knowing
she did not need the birth certificate to enroll Child B. Foster
Parent A reported the school was not allowing her to enroll Child B
in school; and Child B’s worker, FCW 1 was not assisting her with
the documents needed to get Child B enrolled. DCWLA did not
elaborate as to whether Foster Parent A reported needing more
than just Child B’s birth certificate to get Child B enrolled.
On 7/23/2025, I spoke with Program Manager (PM) about the
complaint by telephone. PM denied the allegation. He confirmed
8

Child B’s placement in Foster Parent A’s foster home as of
December 2024 and reported Child B got enrolled in school
timely. He was not sure that enrollment was within 5 days. He
said FCW 1 was in touch with the school, and they were going
back and forth; and in the mix of those contacts, Foster Parent A
reported not wanting Child B to enroll in the school in their home
area. Foster Parent A wanted Child B to go to another school, a
school of choice. PM reported due to Foster Parent A wanting a
“choice school” there was a lack of communication between
Foster Parent A and FCW 1; and getting Child B that choice
school delayed enrollment. He reported these things were also all
happening in December; and there was the holiday break.
On 7/25/2025, I interviewed FCW 2 by telephone. FCW 2 reported
when she was assigned to Child B’s case on 5/12/2025; Child B
was already in school. She said Child B has been enrolled in
School 2, since some time in December 2025 and Child B started
school on 1/6/2025. FCW 2 reported what she understood the
delay in getting Child B enrolled in school was that there was
certain paperwork Foster Parent A needed from FCW 1. FCW 2
was not sure what that paper work was. She said Foster Parent A
reported FCW 1 told her it was hard getting the paper work signed
by the birth parent; but Foster Parent A was not clear on all of
what all was required or needed.
On 7/25/2025 I interviewed FCW 1 by telephone about the
complaint. FCW 1 reported Foster Parent A was insistent that
Child B go to a “choice school,” School 2. FCW 1 reported in
order for Child B to go to that school, a release had to be signed
by the Flint School District according to Foster Parent A. FCW 1
reported Foster Parent A said Foster Parent A was having a
problem getting the release. FCW 1 said she called the Flint
School District a week after 12/7/2024 asking about this release
matter, and what else might be required to get Child B into School
2. She said she also has an email dated 12/12/2024 asking how
to complete the release; and sometime after that, on a day she
was not sure of, the Swartz Creek District, where School 2 is
located in called her to say there was nothing more she could do
to speed up the process and they did not need any other
documents. FCW 1 reported for the Flint School District to give
administrative approval for the enrollment, Foster Parent A
needed to fill out a form that showed she had other children in
School 2. FCW further reported to having a text message from
Foster Parent A dated 12/19/2024 saying Child B is enrolled in
School 2 and Foster Parent A was awaiting a call from School 2
as to what building Child B would be assigned to. FCW 1 reported
9

that since school was out for Christmas break on 12/19/2025,
Child B did not start school at School 2 until 1/6/2025, which was
the first day back from the school’s Christmas break.
On 8/13/2025 I interviewed Foster Parent A by telephone.
Foster Parent A reported Child B was placed with her on
12/6/2024, which was a Saturday. It is noteworthy that 12/7/2024
not 12/6/2024 is a Saturday. Foster Parent A said she had until
12/19/2024 to get Child B enrolled in school. She did not
elaborate as to why that date, but the last day of school before the
school’s Christmas break was 12/20/2024. She acknowledged
trying to get Child A into School 2 and the release process. She
said Child B lateness in getting enrolled in school was due to a
lack of assistance from FCW 1. She reported not being able to get
Child B enrolled without a birth certificate; and that she needed
information about the child’s previous school. She asked FCW 1
for assistance with the documentation, but FCW 1 never provided
her with the birth certificate. Nor was the school release
provided/obtained, which on 12/8/2024 FCW 1 told her she would
provide. Foster Parent A said, she also tried to enroll Child B into
a Charter school that was 2 blocks from her home. FCW 1 would
not provide her the prior school information for the school to
accept Child B. Foster Parent A said she also contacted FCS and
FCS reported her case was not the only case they had and was
not helpful.
Document Review:
Child B’s MISACWIS case record that showed:
o Child B’s placement history information at listed earlier in
this report.
o Child B’s start date at School 2 as 1/6/2025.
o A 12/9/2024 social work contact by FCW 1 that indicated a
home visit was conducted in Child B’s new placement
stating “Foster parents need enrollment paperwork to enroll
Child B in school.”
o No documentation of an email or phone call by FCW 1 to
the school or another entity after Child B’s 12/7/2024
placement related to getting Child A enrolled in school. Nor
documentation of a contact from the school to FCW 1.
o No documentation of a text message showing Child B was
enrolled in school within five day of her 12/7/2024
placement with Foster Parent A.
Internet information related to The Swartz Creek School District
winter break closure:
o School broke for winter break on 12/20/2024.
10

o School resumed 1/6/2025.
Analysis Based on interviews and documents reviewed the evidence
showed Child B entered placement with Foster Parent A on
12/7/2024, and Foster Parent A requested Child B attend a school
outside of her residing area. The school choice request by Foster
Parent A and the fact that the school district broke for winter break
on 12/20/2024 until 1/6/2025 may have created added
complication to the foster parent getting Child B enrolled in that
school timely per the rule. But not a nearby school which Foster
Parent A also attempted to get Child B enrolled in.
The evidence did not show that FCW 1 aided Foster Parent A with
either school enrollment endeavors. Foster Parent A reported a
lack of assistance; and conversely FCW 1 reported assisting by
making a call and emailing the school. Those contacts by FCW 1
are not shown in Child B’s MISACWIS case record
documentation. Additionally, the case record showed a social
contact by FCW 1 on 12/9/2024 that the foster parent needs
enrollment paperwork to enroll Child B in school. There was no
documentation after indicating the paperwork was provided to
Foster Parent A or the school. Nor that paper work was no longer
needed or required. Therein the child was not enrolled within five
days of her placement as required by this rule.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan continuation of the agency
current license status is recommended.
9/25/2025
______________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
September 25, 2025
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
11
